title: Comparing Economic Growth of China and India
Comparing Economic Growth of China and India
section: 1.1 Draft: Final intro should be ~1 page. Can Add/change anything about this.
text:
1.1 Draft: Final intro should be ~1 page. Can Add/change anything about this.
Historically, China has had the largest economic growth since the late 1900’s. However, there has been discussion among pundits regarding whether India’s economic growth will outpace China. We decided to explore this conversation in depth. The main question we would like to propose is: will India’s economic growth outpace China’s in the near or distant future? We would like to analyze how historical trends are progressing/changing and contextualizing these patterns to theorize what is to come for the two countries over the next few decades. For instance, the potential conflicts the two countries will face, effects of climate change, and the influence of technology. There are many factors to consider when analyzing a country’s economic growth; some for instance are gross domestic product (GDP), unemployment rate, inflation rate, trade balance, currency exchange rates, consumer spending, government debt, investment spending, housing market, education levels, etc.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.1 Description
We will examine many datasets available on the World Bank database that compare economic factors of many countries. https://data.worldbank.org/?locations=CN-IN According to the world bank website, these datasets were either gathered by the Bank’s country management units or obtained from official sources from the statistical system of the countries themselves and are updated monthly. One issue with the dataset is that it does not contain data regarding the housing market or education attainment in either country, so we will need to collect these from other sources.
One example in the World Bank database is a dataset that contains the unemployment rates for various countries:
https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SL.UEM.TOTL.ZS?end=2022&locations=CN&name_desc=true&start=1991&view=chart
When downloading the csv file, we see the data contains rows going from 1960 to 2022 and the columns represent the names of different countries including China and India. From this data we will subset the countries to only look at the China and India columns and we will create time series plots to compare the unemployment rate trends in the past 3 decades. We may need to pivot longer to get the years and countries into its own column and into tidydata format.
Moreover, we gathered data describing housing prices in various countries:
https://data.oecd.org/price/housing-prices.htm
One issue with this data is that the data from China only starts from 2010-2022 and the data from India only starts from 2009-2022, but we would like both of these to contain data from previous decades.

2.1.1 Research Plan
Using these datasets, we will be able to compare factors that impact a nation’s economy to determine recent trends in China and India’s economy. Through visualizations comparing these factors faceted by the two countries, we can attempt to predict which country will have stronger economic growth in the future given recent and prior historical trends. First, we will

title: 2  Data
text:
2.2 Missing value analysis
To view any missing data, we subsetted the data to only include China and India, and pivoting the data to include the years as one column. The unemployment data set contains missing values for the years 1960 through 1991. To fix this, we will simply remove the missing values because the 32 years is sufficient data for answering our research question.
